p: In pursuit of high energy density and long cycle life of all‐solid‐state battery, the migration of electron and ion inside cathode is as crucial as the cathode/electrolyte interface. 45, 48, 57, 82, 101, 102, 103, 104 Constructing ion/electron conductive networks in both the cathode and interface is of great significance for reducing the polarization and delivering full capacity of the battery. Tao et al. 48 developed LLZO nanoparticle‐decorated porous carbon foam (LLZO@C) that was used as sulfur host. All‐solid‐state Li‐S battery was assembled using the LLZO@C/S as cathode, Li metal as anode, and LLZO‐P(EO) 8/LiClO 4 as both electrolyte and cathode binder. The LLZO‐P(EO) 8/LiClO 4 electrolyte constructs high‐efficient ionic transportation path among the sulfur particles, which can greatly reduce interfacial resistance between sulfur and LLZO‐P(EO) 8/LiClO 4, and enable the as‐assembled all‐solid‐state Li‐S battery to present remarkable cycling performance at 37 °C. Moreover, Zhu et al. 103 reported a flexible electrolyte/cathode bilayer framework consisting of a 3D carbon nanofiber/sulfur (CNF/S) cathode and 1D LLTO nanofiber‐PEO electrolyte. A mixed conducting behavior was achieved by infiltrating the LLTO‐PEO solid electrolyte onto the surface and into the pores of CNF/S nanofiber membranes, thus this bilayer framework demonstrated outstanding cycle performance with high coulombic efficiency of over 99% at room temperature.
